content.text: Standing on two feet is the stage that for the first time the baby needs to deal with gravity on a small base (2 legs) not like in the former milestones where the base was wide.
Standing is based on all the former milestones that the infant experiences.
There are two ways to stand correctly:  from  kneeling , coming up foot by foot  to standing or from squatting with both legs and stand up without any help.

Preparing the body for walking by using the balance ability of small base - standing on two feet instead of crawling (6 points of touch with the surface) or seating (both arms and legs) that they are a wide base.
Learning to carry the weight of the body on 2 feet and balance between the upper and lower body.

If  you are seeing that your baby is having a hard time achieving the specific milestones described  below or  is at the age of 11 months and canâ€™t do those things, you will  want  to consult with a pediatric or an Infant development guide in order to learn why and how to help  your baby to achieve these important abilities that are the foundation of their physical, sensory and emotional needs:

The space between two legs is too wide
The knees are locked (looks like a bear walking on two legs)
Feet are turning in or out instead of straight/Club Foot
Standing with his back bending forward
The shoulders are higher than they should be
Standing on  tiptoes most of the time
